text: On a (Windows) PC with 4 cores but 8 "logical processors" (as reported by Task Manager) my efforts to speed up some code using multi-threading achieve x3 speedup. Is that "Not bad because the best you can hope for is x4" or is it "Disappointing, because the best you can hope for is x8"?

elements.text: On a (Windows) PC with 4 cores but 8 "logical processors" (as reported by Task Manager) my efforts to speed up some code using multi-threading achieve x3 speedup. Is that "Not bad because the best you can hope for is x4" or is it "Disappointing, because the best you can hope for is x8"?

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>
Absolute best you could hope is roughly x4x1.2

elements.text: Absolute best you could hope is roughly x4x1.2

text: if you are getting good scaling with hyperthreading, something is very unusual about your problem

elements.text: if you are getting good scaling with hyperthreading, something is very unusual about your problem

text: No there's nothing unusual about the problem. There's no IO and (after discovering the joy of running Julia in "track-allocation" mode), not much memory allocation.

elements.text: No there's nothing unusual about the problem. There's no IO and (after discovering the joy of running Julia in "track-allocation" mode), not much memory allocation.

text: yeah. Then 4x is probably as good as you can expect

elements.text: yeah. Then 4x is probably as good as you can expect

text: I'll just have to get a beefier PC - or a better algorithm...

elements.text: I'll just have to get a beefier PC - or a better algorithm...
